Award.AwardTitle: Low Energy, High Precision Muon Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a continuing program of low energy, high precision, muon experiments. The measurements are the MuSun experiment at Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland and the new g-2 experiment at Fermi National Accelerator Facility (FNAL) near Chicago. Both experiments utilize innovative methods to address questions ranging from the testing of the Standard Model to the nature of the weak nuclear interaction. The MuSun experiment at PSI will measure the lifetime of the muonic deuterium atom to a precision of about 10 parts-per-million. The measurement will determine the muonic deuterium doublet capture rate to unrivaled accuracy of 1.5%. The New g-2 experiment at FNAL will measure the muon's anomalous magnetic moment to a precision of about 0.14 ppm. The measurement addresses the tantalizing discrepancy between the BNL E821 result and the Standard Model calculation of the muon anomaly and offers a probe of new particles and undetected forces that uniquely complements the physics reach of the Large Hadron Collider.

The project involves several areas of broader impact and broader significance. The PI will continue his involvement of high school students, physics majors and physics graduate students in research activities. The group's involvement in high-speed data acquisition and high-volume data analysis will expose our students to many aspects of cutting-edge computer hardware/software. The proposed measurements of textbook quantities including fundamental parameters and basic interactions will have wide-range impact in nuclear, particle and astrophysics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involves a continuing program of precision measurements involving sub-atomic particles called muons. 

In the muon g-2 experiment, being conducted at  Fermi National Accelerator Facility (Fermilab)  near Chicago, Illinois, we will measure to roughly 100 parts-per-billion precision the muon's anomalous magnetic moment. This fundamental quantity is both measurable and calculable to extraordinary accuracy. It thereby offers an important test the Standard Model of particle physics and enables the search for new particles and unknown forces of nature.


In the MuSun experiment being conducted at Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) near Zurich, Switzerland we will measure the lifetime of muonic deuterium atoms (muonic atoms are exotic atoms in which a muon replacesan ordinary electron). The lifetime measurement will enable the determination of the so-called muonic deuterium capture rate. This weak interaction process is a close cousin of hydrogen burning in the sun's interior and offers an important test of our theoretical understanding of solar thermonuclear fusion.

 
During this grant period we developed and prototyped the 20 Gbyte-per-second data acquisition system to be used for the g-2 experiment. The installation and commissioning of the data acquisition system is now underway at Fermilab with data taking expected to begin in early 2017.

During this grant period we collected and analysed data from the MuSun experiment. We have determined various atomic / molecular parameters that are necessary for the interpretation of the experiment. Our first results for the muonic deuterium capture rate are expected in the near future.
